1.title: Nigerian Scams
1.content: Imagine, one day, you come home from a long day and you want to rest in your sofa with your coffee and just enjoy your life before it ends. And then you get a phone call. Is it your annoying boss, your old classmate, or the electricity company complaining you didn‚Äôt pay your bills? No. It‚Äôs the Nigerian prince! And he wants to send you some money! .

2.title: How do they work?
2.content: In ‚Äò419‚Äô scams (called so because 419 is the country code for Nigeria, and the Nigerian Prince scam is the most famously known 419 scam), you‚Äôll receive an email, usually from someone claiming to be extremely rich. For whatever reason, they‚Äôll say they need to transfer money through your account, and they‚Äôll tell you that you will get a handsome cut of the money (some scammers pretend to be businesses giving out loans or looking to find business partners). After getting your personal details (usually to sell online to others), they will usually ask you for a ‚Äòsmall‚Äô fee, usually via apps like PayPal, Western Union, CashApp and Zelle. Once you‚Äôve given them the money, they‚Äôll ghost you.

3.title: What to do against them?
3.content: Give the scammers fake information, like fake accounts and fake banks, and try to waste their time by ‚Äúentering the wrong password‚Äù or something alike. Also, report the scams on scammer.info.

5.content: What to do if all goes wrong? Well first of all don‚Äôt panic, you can always just hang up the phone and turn off your phone/PC, they won‚Äôt be able to do anything anymore. Block the number, turn off everything for 10 or so minutes, etc.

6.title: Tech support scams
6.content: Your average day toggling on your PC messaging people or browsing the web. Nothing odd. Then, suddenly, your screen starts flickering and beep sounds come out. It says your computer has a virus! But luckily, there is a number you can call‚Ä¶ .

7.title: How do they work
7.content: After you call that number, a scammer posing as a technician will tell you to let him access your PC via remote software control to then abuse the power. He can look through your private data, try to get you to access your bank, install even more malware on your PC, etc.

8.title: How to bait
8.content: What you can do to piss these people off is to, make them believe you fell for this scam. You can set up a VM and act as if that is your actual computer, giving them access to it without risking your own data. Just be sure to set up a lot of fake data to make it actually believable. And of course you can always make them waste a lot of time pretending that something takes long. If your screen blackens, that is usually a technique scammers use to make their victims not see what they are actually doing.

9.title: Requirements
9.content: A VM, preferably Windows 10 or 11, lot of fake data, preferably some online persona too. If you‚Äôre dealing with some guy that wants to get to your bank, then a fake bank too.

11.title: What is Scambaiting?
11.content: Scambaiting is what we call when we call scammers, pretend to be ordinary people, potential victims of their scam, and waste their time and effort. When scambaiting, it is also beneficial collect as much possible information about the scammers as possible in order to report and warn others about the scam/call center.
